questions.question_text:
Joe, a user, provides the requirements for a new gaming PC to the assigned technician. Joe wants the PC to have high-quality graphics, audio/video, and storage.
In addition, the PC must be able to:
✑ Store a large amount of data
✑ Stream HD graphics, videos, and music

Have fast and redundant storage -
//IMG//

Which of the following will BEST meet these requirements? (Choose two.)
A technician wants to block remote logins to a server. Which of the following ports should be blocked?

comments.content: it sure is. TCP and UDP

discussion.content: I had an exam today and there was option of 53 instead of 23.

A – TELNET provides remote login to a server via port 23
B -- FTP enables you to log in to a remote system via port 21 for client connecting to servers -
1. Open a connection to a remote system by using the ftp command. $ ftp remote-system -
2. Type your user name
3. If prompted, type your password.

o block remote logins to a server, the technician should block the following ports commonly used for remote login services:

Port 22 (SSH - Secure Shell): Used for remote login to Unix/Linux servers. Blocking this port will prevent SSH connections, which are often used for secure remote administration.

Port 3389 (RDP - Remote Desktop Protocol): Used for remote login to Windows servers. Blocking this port will prevent RDP connections, which are commonly used for remote desktop access to Windows machines.

Port 23 (Telnet): Used for remote login over Telnet, an older protocol that transmits data in plaintext and is less secure than SSH. Blocking this port will prevent Telnet access, which is typically avoided in favor of SSH.
Port 22 or Port 23
it should say 23 (telnet) not dns (domain name system). Telnet: a network protocol that allows a user on one computer to log into another computer that is part of the same network.

Selected Answer: B
The answer should be port 23....so change port 53 to port 23, as other sites show.

None of the answers are correct; for remote there only two ports mainly which are,
either 23 telnet and 3389 remote DP,
Port (20- and 21 are File transfer protocol)
Es la respuesta mas adecuada, en base a la pregunta.
Option C on The VCE file is 23 not 53, This makes more sense none of the answers provided here make any sense.FTP maybe but Thats remote logon to a file server which is a MickeyMouse Answer.

comments.content: Option B on the VCE is 23 correction*
opps sorry I meant to say 23 and 22

discussion.content: The only port numbers that can connect to a server remotely to issue command is port 21 (telnet) and port 22 (SSH). All the other answers are wrong ... -_- smh

Explanation: As is the trend with many tests, I think the reason Port 21 is the correct answer here is because all the other answers are so obviously wrong. Port 53 is DNS, Port 80 is HTTP and port 443 is HTTPS. None of those answers have to do with accessing a server remotely, Port 21 (FTP) would be the closest answer to a remote access of a server.

BRUH, port 21 is ftp what does it have to do with anything? I saw this question before with different answer choices but none of the ones provided here are correct. Usually the answer would be port 23 which is Telnet.
This one is definitely wrong. The correct answer would either be port 22 or 23
rdp is 443 surely this is the answer confused

comments.content: port 443 is for HTTPS for securing websites

This is correct. 3389 is RDP (Remote Desktop Protocol). 443 is HTTPS and is only correct if you're unable to access an HTTPS website. 

As is the trend with many tests, I think the reason Port 21 is the correct answer here is because all the other answers are so obviously wrong. Port 53 is DNS, Port 80 is HTTP and port 443 is HTTPS. None of those answers have to do with accessing a server remotely, Port 21 (FTP) would be the closest answer to a remote access of a server.
You can also use Port 22 (ssh). They probably typo

questions.question_text: Which of the following types of cables is used to provide high-speed voice and data connections in a datacenter to Layer 3 devices?

A customer wants to install a new computer in a room that does not have any network drops. The customer authorizes a technician to install a new network jack in the room. Which of the following tools should the technician use to finish installing the new network jack?

discussion.content:
"Which of the following tools should the technician use to finish installing the new network jack?"

From this We are going to use a "network jack" or "ethernet wall socket" and for it we need a Punch down tool.

"Crimper" is used when you are making an ethernet cable, with CAT 6 cable and RJ45 connector.
The same question on this site was asked earlier and the answer was Crimper.... I swear this whole CompTIA this is a scam.

Selected Answer: C
A network drop is a connection point in a network. The term generally refers to a local area network (LAN). Network drops are typically wall outlets with an Ethernet jack (RJ45) that a computer or other network device, including a phone, printer, etc. can plug into.

The keyword here is 'new jack'. It has to be Crimper - C. Punchdown tools are used at patch panels to connect the Ethernet cables to 110 blocks without using RJ45 Jack, just wires.

comments.content:
MY BAD - the context is about the network drop point. So in this case a 'new jack' must be a new ethernet wall port
The video showing how to do it - https://www.youtube.com/watch?time_continue=946&v=uFBQsUwqy_g&feature=emb_title

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Punchdown Tool to connect the patchpanel and the Wall network jack. 
The question is not to end a cable with a RJ45-Plug

Selected Answer: D
I think it's D - punchdown tool

this question is dumb since both is possible, both the wall and clear end are called a jack. I'm guessing the crimp is the answer because it can directly connect to the PC without a patch. Realistically you would put the wall jack and a plate and terminate it with a punch down tool to make it look nice.
The answer is C. The question states a new computer, 1 each. So there only needs to be one line run and doesn't need to be terminated in a patch panel.
the answer is D punch down tool. crimpers are used to terminate ethernet cable ends
the answer is D. Punchdown tool

questions.question_text:
A user is working on a Windows laptop in a conference room that has connectivity to a large-screen TV. The user attempts to connect to the TV using HDMI and
VGA cables, but video does not display on the TV. Which of the following is the MOST likely cause of the issue?

comments.content: If its a mismatch in resolution then the screen would still display but just not in the correct resolution

discussion.content: Cant be screen mirroring surely has to be A. You can do screen mirroring without HDMI! What do you guys think?
screen mirroring is for wireless connection, isn't it? with a HDMI or VGA cable you don't need screen mirroring.
I think it's correct, screen mirroring needs to be enabled first in the laptop settings.
You can do screen mirroring with VGA
